questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented to the medicine OPD with complaints of abdominal cramps and bloody and mucopurulent stools. His vitals are- temperature -100.4.°:F, Pulse 120 BPM, and RR-24 /min. Upon investigation, gram-negative, non-sporing, non-motile bacilli were isolated. The bacteria showed pale colonies on MacConkey agar. Which is the most common species implicated in the suspected disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Shigella sonnei is the most common cause of bacillary dysentery in developed and urbanized regions, and fits the clinical, microscopic, and culture characteristics described.

  • The clinical picture is of acute bacillary dysentery-characterized by bloody and mucopurulent stools with abdominal cramps and mild fever.
  • The key microbiological findings are:
    • Gram-negative rods
    • Non-sporing
    • Non-motile
    • Pale colonies on MacConkey agar (due to no lactose fermentation)
  • These are classical features of Shigella species, and among them:
    • Shigella sonnei is the most prevalent species in developed and urban settings, and is increasing in incidence in parts of India due to improving sanitation and urbanization.
    • It causes a milder form of dysentery compared to Shigella dysenteriae, but is more epidemiologically common.
    • Shigella species invade the colonic mucosa and cause inflammation, ulceration, and bleeding, resulting in dysentery.

Explanation of other options:

Salmonella typhi (Option A): Causes enteric (typhoid) fever, not dysentery. Associated with step-ladder fever, bradycardia, rose spots, and constipation early on; not bloody, mucopurulent diarrhea.

Campylobacter jejuni (Option C): Though it causes bloody diarrhea, it is motile, shows curved/comma-shaped rods, and is oxidase positive. It does not match the culture findings described.

Clostridium botulinum (Option D): An anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming rod. It causes flaccid paralysis due to neurotoxin, not dysentery, and has no relevance to the current clinical picture.

questions.text: Ramesh, a young engineer, presented to the ENT OPD with complaints of bilateral nasal obstruction. Suresh, who is his roommate, says that there is a foul-smelling discharge from Ramesh's nose, which baffles him since he cannot smell anything. On external examination, the nose is hardened and has a 'woody feel', as shown in the image below. Anterior rhinoscopy shows excessive crusting in both nasal cavities. On removing the crusts, the ENT resident observes wide, roomy cavities. Ramesh undergoes an RT-PCR test for COVID-19, which is negative. Based on this history, the doctor orders a biopsy, whose findings reveal 'Mikulicz cells'. Which of the following bacteria would you expect to see in the specimen?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis causes rhinoscleroma, a chronic granulomatous infection of the nose characterized by Mikulicz cells and a woody, indurated nose.

The patient presents with classical features of rhinoscleroma, a chronic granulomatous disease of the upper respiratory tract, especially the nasal mucosa, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

  • Key features in this case:
    • Woody induration of the nose
    • Crusting with wide, roomy nasal cavities
    • Foul-smelling discharge with anosmia (loss of smell)
    • Presence of Mikulicz cells:
      • These are large, foamy macrophages containing the causative organism, diagnostic of rhinoscleroma.
    • Rhinoscleroma progresses through 3 stages:
      • Catarrhal/Atrophic stage - mucosal congestion and discharge
      • Granulomatous stage - formation of nodular masses, Mikulicz cells
      • Sclerotic stage- fibrosis and sclerosis of nasal structures
    • Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis is a subspecies of Klebsiella pneumoniae and is a gram-negative, non-motile, capsulated bacillus.

Explanation of other options:

Serratia marcescens (Option C): Opportunistic pathogen in nosocomial infections; does not cause chronic granulomatous disease or rhinoscleroma.

choices.text: UTI cannot be confirmed from this sample

questions.text: A female had been admitted to the surgical ward for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She had been passing urine well post-operatively, and her general condition was improving. However, on post-op day 3, the patient developed fever, burning pain on micturition. The attending on rounds informs his residents that the patient might have developed UTI, one of the leading causes of hospital-acquired infections(HAI). The resident obtains a clean catch midstream urine sample and sends the sample to the microbiology department for colony count. What is the count for significant bacteriuria in the following patient, as suggested by the Kass criteria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to Kass criteria, a colony count of >10&sup5; CFU/ml from a midstream urine sample indicates significant bacteriuria.

  • The Kass criteria are a standard microbiological guideline used to diagnose significant bacteriuria, particularly in asymptomatic or catheterized patients.
  • In symptomatic females with uncomplicated UTI, >10&sup5; colony-forming units (CFU)/ml in a clean-catch midstream urine sample is considered diagnostic of a true urinary tract infection, rather than contamination.
  • This threshold helps differentiate between actual infection and mere presence of bacteria due to improper collection or contamination.
  • Hospital-acquired UTIs are a common form of nosocomial infection, especially in postoperative settings.
  • The presentation of fever and dysuria (burning micturition) on post-op day 3 suggests an ascending infection, likely due to catheterization or instrumentation.
  • Therefore, a proper urine culture with colony count is essential.

Explanation of other options:

Single bacterial isolate (Option B): While a single organism increases the likelihood of true infection, colony count is essential for confirmation. A pure isolate with low CFU is not diagnostic.

UTI cannot be confirmed from this sample (Option C): A clean-catch midstream sample is appropriate for culture. If properly collected, it is a valid diagnostic sample.

>1000 CFU/ml (Option D): This count is considered significant in catheterized patients, not in standard clean-catch midstream samples from non-catheterized individuals.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2875701/

questions.text: Which of the following E.coli species produces a toxin that acts by inhibiting 28s rRNA of the 60s subunit, thus inhibiting protein synthesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces Shiga-like toxin that inhibits 28S rRNA of the 60S ribosomal subunit, blocking protein synthesis.

  • EHEC (especially the O157:H7 serotype) is known for producing a Shiga-like toxin (verotoxin) that is structurally and functionally similar to the toxin produced by Shigella dysenteriae.
  • This toxin binds to Gb3 receptors on intestinal and renal endothelial cells and cleaves a specific adenine residue from the 28S rRNA in the 60S ribosomal subunit.
  • This disrupts ribosomal function, halting protein synthesis, leading to cell death.
  • Clinically, EHEC causes bloody diarrhea with little or no fever and can result in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), especially in children.

Explanation of other options:

ETEC (Option A): Produces heat-labile (LT) and heat-stable (ST) enterotoxins that stimulate cAMP and cGMP, respectively, causing secretory diarrhea, but do not inhibit ribosomal function.

DAEC (Option B): Diffusely adherent E. coli is associated with pediatric diarrhea through its unique adhesion mechanisms; it does not produce Shiga-like toxins.

UPEC (Option D): Uropathogenic E. coli causes UTIs and relies on virulence factors like P fimbriae, hemolysin, and siderophores, not on inhibition of protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of chronic anemia requiring repeated transfusions presents with fever, left knee pain, and restricted joint movement. Examination shows a warm, tender knee joint. Laboratory work-up reveals anemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL), indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and hemoglobin electrophoresis with 92% HbS. The clinician suspects acute osteomyelitis. Which of the following organisms is most commonly implicated in such cases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Salmonella is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia.

  • Patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) are particularly prone to osteomyelitis due to functional asplenia, which impairs the clearance of encapsulated organisms like Salmonella.
  • Repeated infarctions in bone also predispose to seeding by hematogenous organisms.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis overall, Salmonella is classically associated with sickle cell disease.
  • The Hb electrophoresis in this patient (92% HbS) confirms sickle cell anemia, explaining the predisposition.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Most common cause of osteomyelitis in the general population, but not characteristically associated with sickle cell disease.

Eikenella sps (Option C): A rare cause of osteomyelitis, more commonly associated with human bite wounds or periodontal infections.

Pseudomonas (Option D): More common in puncture wounds–associated osteomyelitis or IV drug users, not typical in sickle cell-related cases.

questions.text: A public health officer is investigating a sudden outbreak of plague in a high-altitude village. Multiple individuals from the same family present with an acute onset of fever, hemoptysis, and dyspnea. Radiographic findings show bilateral infiltrates. The infection is spreading rapidly among close contacts despite no known exposure to fleas or rodents. Which form of Yersinia pestis infection is most likely involved in this outbreak?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pneumonic plague is the only form of Yersinia pestis infection that spreads via person-to-person respiratory droplets.

  • Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, manifests in three main clinical forms-bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic.
  • Bubonic plague, the most common, results from flea bites and presents with painful lymphadenopathy (buboes). (Option A ruled out)
  • Septicemic plague can occur as a progression of bubonic form or independently, leading to widespread bacterial dissemination. (Option B ruled out)
  • However, pneumonic plague is unique in that it can be transmitted directly from person to person via aerosolized respiratory droplets, especially in crowded settings.
  • This form is highly contagious and often fatal without prompt treatment, warranting strict public health measures.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is associated with the production of a non-diffusible red pigment, leading to the appearance of pseudohemoptysis (red-colored sputum), often mistaken for blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serratia marcescens produces a red pigment (prodigiosin), which can mimic blood in sputum.

  • Serratia marcescens is a gram-negative bacillus belonging to the Enterobacteriaceae family.
  • It is notable for producing prodigiosin, a red, non-diffusible pigment.
  • This pigment may accumulate on moist surfaces or respiratory secretions, leading to pseudohemoptysis-the appearance of red sputum resembling blood.
  • This can lead to diagnostic confusion with hemoptysis.
  • Although environmental in origin, S. marcescens is also an opportunistic pathogen implicated in nosocomial infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals and patients with catheters or ventilators.

Explanation of other options:

Enterobacter (Option B): Does not produce red pigment; commonly causes hospital-acquired UTIs and pneumonia.

Citrobacter (Option C): Lacks pigment production; primarily associated with neonatal meningitis and UTIs.

Klebsiella ozaenae (Option D): Associated with chronic atrophic rhinitis (ozena); not known for red pigment or pseudohemoptysis.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of a step ladder pattern of fever for 2 weeks comes to the medicine OPD. Which of the following investigations is the most sensitive for culture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bone marrow aspirate culture has the highest sensitivity for detecting Salmonella Typhi, especially after antibiotic administration.

  • Salmonella Typhi causes typhoid fever, which typically presents with step-ladder pattern fever, abdominal discomfort, and sometimes rose spots.
  • Diagnosis relies heavily on culture techniques.
  • Among all specimens, bone marrow aspirate has the highest sensitivity, even in patients who have already started antibiotics, with detection rates approaching 90–95%.
  • This is because the bacteria persist in the reticuloendothelial system longer than in peripheral blood, urine, or stool.
  • Though invasive, it is especially useful in chronic or treated cases.

Explanation of other options:

Blood (Option A): Sensitivity is highest in the first week (~60-80%), but drops if antibiotics are started.

Stool and Urine (Option B): More useful in later stages (2nd-3rd week), but sensitivity is lower and inconsistent.

Duodenal aspirate (Option D): May help in chronic carriers, but is not the most sensitive during active infection.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the ER with a classical pain migrating from the umbilicus to the right iliac fossa. He also had a fever for 2 days, abdominal pain, and tenderness. The resident on duty ordered a USG, suspecting it to be an appendix pathology. However, the USG was inconclusive. The resident then brought this up with his consultant, who explained that a particular Gram-negative infection causes mesenteric adenitis, which closely resembles appendicitis. Which organism is he referring to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Yersinia enterocolitica can cause mesenteric lymphadenitis, mimicking acute appendicitis in adolescents and children.

  • Yersinia enterocolitica is a Gram-negative, bipolar-staining coccobacillus transmitted via contaminated food (especially pork) or water.
  • It primarily infects the terminal ileum and mesenteric lymph nodes.
  • In children and adolescents, it causes mesenteric adenitis, which presents with fever, right lower quadrant pain, and leukocytosis-clinically resembling acute appendicitis.
  • USG or CT may reveal enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes, but not an inflamed appendix.
  • This pseudo-appendicitis presentation is a hallmark of Y. enterocolitica infection, especially in developed countries or temperate climates.

Explanation of other options:

E.coli (Option A): While E. coli causes diarrheal diseases and UTIs, it does not typically mimic appendicitis via mesenteric adenitis.

Salmonella typhi (Option C): Causes enteric fever with prolonged step-ladder fever, abdominal discomfort, and splenomegaly, but not mesenteric adenitis mimicking appendicitis.

Shigella (Option D): Causes bloody diarrhea (bacillary dysentery) due to mucosal invasion of the colon, not RLQ pain mimicking appendicitis.

questions.text:
You come across the following culture media for gram negative bacilli, wherein bacteria which ferment the substance present in the media produce bright pink colonies while non fermenters produce pale colonies. Which type of agar would this be?

i. Simple media
ii. Enrichment media
iii. Differential media
iv. Enriched media
v. Selective media
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medium shown is MacConkey agar, which is both selective (for Gram-negative bacteria) and differential (based on lactose fermentation).

  • The culture plate in the image shows pink colonies on a pink background on one side and pale colonies on the other.
  • This is characteristic of MacConkey agar, which is commonly used for isolating Gram-negative bacilli, especially from enteric specimens.
  • Why is it Differential Media (iii):
    • It differentiates lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters:
      • Lactose fermenters (e.g., E. coli) → pink colonies due to acid production turning the pH indicator (neutral red) pink.
      • Non-lactose fermenters (e.g., Salmonella, Shigella) → pale or colorless colonies.
  • Why is it Selective Media (v):
  • Contains bile salts and crystal violet to inhibit the growth of Gram-positive organisms, allowing only Gram-negative bacteria to grow.
  • Simple media (e.g., nutrient agar) do not differentiate or select
  • Enrichment media: Used to favor the growth of specific pathogens in liquid form
  • Enriched media: Contain added nutrients like blood or serum (e.g., blood agar)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male developed arthritis type knee pain 7 months after an episode of dysentery with Shigella. A diagnosis of reactive arthritis was made. Which HLA is commonly associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HLA-B27 is strongly associated with reactive arthritis, particularly after gastrointestinal infections like dysentery caused by Shigella.

  • Reactive arthritis (ReA) is an autoimmune condition that typically develops after an infection, most commonly gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections, such as dysentery caused by Shigella or Salmonella.
  • The onset of arthritis occurs 1-4 weeks after the infection.
  • HLA-B27 is strongly linked with the development of reactive arthritis.
  • This genetic association is seen in a significant proportion of patients with reactive arthritis, particularly those who develop knee pain, heel pain, or sacroiliitis.
  • HLA-B27 is part of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system, which plays a role in the immune system's ability to recognize foreign pathogens.
  • The presence of HLA-B27 is thought to contribute to an abnormal immune response in reactive arthritis, triggering inflammation in the joints.

Explanation of other options:

HLA-B54 (Option A): There is no strong association between HLA-B54 and reactive arthritis. It is not a typical marker for autoimmune or inflammatory arthritis syndromes.

HLA-DR04 (Option B): HLA-DR04 is more commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases, but it is not typically linked to reactive arthritis.

HLA-B51 (Option D): HLA-B51 is associated with Behçet's disease, not with reactive arthritis. It is involved in the pathogenesis of this condition, which primarily causes oral and genital ulcers and uveitis.

questions.text: Which is the only shigella species which does not test positive for the following biochemical reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Shigella dysenteriae is the only catalase-negative Shigella species, unlike others, which are catalase-positive.

  • The catalase test is a key biochemical test used to differentiate bacteria based on the presence of the enzyme catalase, which breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, producing bubbles (positive result).
  • In the genus Shigella, all species except Shigella dysenteriae are catalase-positive.
  • dysenteriae lacks catalase and hence gives a negative test (no bubbles).
  • This biochemical property helps differentiate S. dysenteriae in the laboratory.
  • Thus, when performing a catalase test (as shown in the image), the absence of bubbling helps identify S. dysenteriae.

Explanation of other options:

Shigella flexneri (Option B): Catalase-positive; produces bubbles on the catalase test.

Shigella boydii (Option C): Catalase-positive; shows bubble formation.

Shigella sonnei (Option D): Also catalase-positive; bubbles observed during the catalase test.

choices.text: Motile with peritrichous flagella, lactose fermenting
Motile with peritrichous flagella, non-lactose fermenting

questions.text: A 68-year-old alcoholic presented to the emergency room with high-grade fever for 5 days and sputum of 'red currant jelly' colour. His vitals are- fever 101.4°C, pulse 120 bpm, BP 90/60 mmHg of hg and RR 30/min. Upon admission, his chest X-ray showed upper lobe consolidation with a 'bulging fissure' sign. Match the implicated bacteria's motility and their property on MacConkey agar.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Klebsiella pneumoniae, the likely pathogen, is non-motile and produces pink colonies on MacConkey agar due to its ability to ferment lactose.

  • The clinical presentation of a chronic alcoholic with high-grade fever, hypotension, and 'red currant jelly' sputum is classic for Klebsiella pneumoniae infection, a common cause of severe lobar pneumonia in debilitated patients.
  • On imaging, bulging fissure sign and upper lobe consolidation are hallmark radiological findings of Klebsiella pneumonia.
  • This sign occurs due to the production of thick, mucoid exudates that expand the affected lobe.
  • Biochemical properties of Klebsiella pneumoniae:
    • Motility: It is non-motile (lacks flagella).
    • Lactose fermentation: It ferments lactose, producing pink mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar, a key diagnostic feature.
    • It also possesses a prominent polysaccharide capsule, contributing to its virulence and the characteristic mucoid appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Motile with peritrichous flagella, lactose fermenting (Option A): Describes E. coli, which is motile and lactose-fermenting, but doesn’t produce red currant jelly sputum or bulging fissure sign.

Non-motile, non-lactose fermenting (Option B): Could suggest organisms like Shigella, which are non-motile but do not ferment lactose and are not associated with pneumonia.

Motile with peritrichous flagella, non-lactose fermenting (Option C): Typical of Proteus spp., which are motile and non-lactose fermenting, but do not cause typical lobar pneumonia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male chronic alcoholic presents with a 4-day history of fever, cough, and shortness of breath, accompanied by episodes of blood-tinged sputum. What would be the characteristics of the likely bacteria involved in his symptoms?
questions.solution:
One-line explanation:

Klebsiella pneumoniae forms mucoid colonies due to its thick polysaccharide capsule, contributing to its virulence and typical presentation in alcoholics.

  • Klebsiella pneumoniae is a Gram-negative, encapsulated, non-motile bacillus that commonly causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and debilitated patients.
  • The pneumonia is typically severe, with production of thick, blood-tinged sputum referred to as "currant jelly" sputum.
  • One of the most distinctive features of Klebsiella is its prominent capsule, which appears as mucoid colonies on culture media like MacConkey agar.
  • The capsule not only helps in evading phagocytosis but also enhances virulence and contributes to the organism's resistance to host defenses.
  • The upper lobe involvement and bulging fissure sign on imaging are also typical.

Mnemonic: ABCDE's of Klebsiella: Aspiration pneumonia, abscess in lungs and liver, 'Currant jelly' sputum, Diabetes mellitus, EtOH overuse.

Explanation of other options:

Bloody diarrhea (Option B): Seen in Shigella, EHEC, and other enteroinvasive pathogens, not in Klebsiella pneumoniae, which primarily affects the respiratory tract.

Pseudoappendicitis (Option C): Typically associated with Yersinia enterocolitica due to mesenteric lymphadenitis mimicking appendicitis, not a feature of Klebsiella.

Hyponatremia (Option D): Commonly seen in Legionella pneumophila infection, which also causes atypical pneumonia, but not typically with red currant jelly sputum or mucoid colonies.

questions.text: A patient presents with weakness in the legs following a diarrheal infection a week ago. If a rectal swab is used for culture of the organism responsible for her symptoms, which transport medium can be used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cary-Blair medium is specifically designed to preserve enteric pathogens like Campylobacter jejuni, often implicated in post-infectious neurological conditions.

  • The clinical scenario suggests Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), a post-infectious demyelinating polyneuropathy that commonly follows a Campylobacter jejuni infection.
  • Campylobacter is a curved, motile, Gram-negative rod that causes gastroenteritis, often from undercooked poultry or contaminated water.
  • To isolate Campylobacter from stool or rectal swab specimens, it's crucial to use a medium that preserves the viability of the organism during transport without allowing overgrowth of commensals.
  • Cary-Blair transport medium is the standard transport medium used for enteric pathogens like Campylobacter, Salmonella, Shigella, and Vibrio.
  • It is a semi-solid, low-nutrient medium with minimal buffering, maintaining the organism's survival during transit to the lab.

Explanation of other options:

Stuart's transport medium (Option B): Used for transporting specimens for fastidious organisms like Neisseria gonorrhoeae, not for enteric pathogens like Campylobacter.

Amies transport medium (Option C): Modified Stuart’s medium, typically used for throat, wound, and genital specimens, is not ideal for fecal or rectal swabs for enteric bacteria.

Sachs buffered Glycerol saline (Option D): Primarily used for transporting Shigella, but not ideal for Campylobacter, which is more fragile and requires a specialized medium like Cary-Blair.

questions.text: A patient presenting with cough, fever, and diagnosed with pneumonia caused by Escherichia coli in isolation. What is the key virulence factor that enables E. coli to cause respiratory infections in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The K capsule in E. coli is a critical virulence factor that inhibits phagocytosis, enabling it to cause respiratory infections such as pneumonia.

  • Although Escherichia coli is most commonly known as an enteric pathogen, it can cause extraintestinal infections like urinary tract infections, neonatal meningitis, and, less commonly, hospital-acquired pneumonia in immunocompromised or ventilated patients.
  • Among its numerous virulence factors, the K capsule plays a pivotal role in evading the host immune response.
  • The polysaccharide capsule provides resistance to phagocytosis and complement-mediated killing, allowing the organism to survive in lung tissue and cause pneumonia.
  • This capsular antigen is especially important in invasive strains of E. coli and is associated with severe extraintestinal infections.
  • In the respiratory tract, the capsule helps prevent recognition and destruction by alveolar macrophages.

Explanation of other options:

Fimbriae (Option A): These aid in adhesion to epithelial cells, particularly in urinary and gastrointestinal infections, but are not the primary factor in respiratory tract infections.

LPS endotoxin (Option B): While LPS contributes to systemic inflammation and septic shock, it is a general virulence factor and not specific for pneumonia pathogenesis.

All of the above (Option D): While all these contribute to E. coli virulence, only the K capsule is the key factor specifically enabling respiratory infection by preventing phagocytosis in the lungs.
